instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PPVCCSA_S0_CPU: What is PPVCCSA_S0_CPU? Main power rail for the CPU. If this is missing the machine will act braindead. This is NOT shorted to ground if it has a low resistance – this is a common mistake people make. A chip that requires high power at a low voltage like a CPU or GPU will have a low measured resistance to ground..
definitions.R7402: What is R7402? Resistor between PPVIN_S0_CPUIMVP and CPUIMVP_TON. TON stands for TIME ON – CPUIMVP_TON configures the buck converter for the CPU based on its input power supply. If this resistor is blown, the machine will turn on but not have any image, chime, or POST, because CPU vcore will be missing. This resistor is often the first to corrode because it is along a high voltage rail and it is right on the edge of the board, check this on 2011-2012 model Macbook Pros that turn on and do not chime. .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_CPU: What is PPVCORE_S0_CPU? This is the primary power rail for the CPU that powers the CPU, known as CPU vcore. Without this, the machine will be braindead. .
definitions.PP1V8_S0: What is PP1V8_S0? PP1V8_S0 is a power rail that is present when the machine is in an S0 state, meaning it is fully turned on, not sleeping or hiberating .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 0V
threads.message:
Clean board, client states that Mac started to have issues starting up, but once was on it worked fine, sometimes it took many tries to get it to start.

<CAPACITOR>C6603</CAPACITOR> was partially shorted and burned (<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>) after replacement diode reading is correct but board still has same problem.

Already tried heating up PCH but same problem, tried new SMC and same thing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 0V
threads.message: Which voltages do you actually get on the MLB?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 0V
threads.message: I forgot you cannot yet read my mind sorry, MLB makes it all the way to 0.9V on <SIGNAL>PPVCCSA_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>, I get USB power but no activity, already tried clean bios as well.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 0V
threads.message:
Check basic voltages of <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>; pins 19, 29, 46, 47.
Also check <RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR>/03.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 0V
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 0V
threads.message:
So missing <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>.
Remove <TRANSISTOR>Q7950</TRANSISTOR> and test again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 0V
threads.message: Right, after removing <TRANSISTOR>Q7950</TRANSISTOR>  <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> only went up to 0.3V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 0V
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 0V
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 0V
threads.message:
<CHIP>U7400</CHIP> gets 3V at pin 47?
Do you note a drop pulse at pins 1 & 48?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 0V
threads.message:
<CHIP>U7400</CHIP> gets 3V at pin 47? negative, board gets 0.3V there too.

Do you note a drop pulse at pins 1 & 48? No, when I plug charger it starts at 12V and stays there on both pins.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 0V
threads.message:
Sorry for my error.
I was thinking you've got 3V at <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>; you have 0.3V instead.

Do you get correct voltage at all other big coils (apart of VCORE)?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 0V
threads.message:
No problem,  <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is 0.3V also.
L7760 <SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0</SIGNAL> is 0.03V 
L7550 is 0V
All other coils get their propper voltage

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 0V
threads.message:
Check diode mode to ground at L7760.
Post <CHIP>U7760</CHIP> voltages; IN, EN, SS/REFIN.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 0V
threads.message:
Diode mode to ground at L7760 is 204
<CHIP>U7760</CHIP> 
IN 0.3V
EN 1.05v
SS/REFIN 0V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 0V
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 0V
threads.message: <TRANSISTOR>Q7830</TRANSISTOR> was the culprit of all the problems, thanks a lot for your help!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 0V
threads.message: Initially replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7830</TRANSISTOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7810</TRANSISTOR> and board worked a few times but it failed again, then replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7812</TRANSISTOR> and so far it is still working.
